case_id: State of Rajasthan v. Om Prakash (2002) 5 SCC 745
facts: Marriage between Om Prakash (Respondent No. 1/Accused) and Kamlesh (deceased) solemnized on 25.04.1988.
Kamlesh died due to burn injuries at her matrimonial home in Village Mandawara, District Nagaur, Rajasthan on 08.09.1988.
The death occurred within approximately 4.5 months of the marriage.
Initial report (Ex. P-3) lodged by Om Prakash suggested accidental death due to stove bursting while preparing tea.

Bhanwar Lal (PW-2, father of the deceased) lodged a First Information Report (FIR) (Ex. P-1) on 09.09.1988 alleging that his daughter was harassed for dowry (demand for TV and Fridge) and killed by her husband and in-laws.
Prosecution witnesses, including PW-2 (father), PW-4 (Smt. Kamla, mother), and PW-6 (Jetha Ram, uncle), testified about dowry demands and harassment meted out to Kamlesh soon after marriage.
PW-2 testified he visited Kamlesh at her matrimonial home and observed her distress, and the accused complained about insufficient dowry.
Post-mortem report (Ex. P-11) indicated death due to shock as a result of extensive (90%) ante-mortem burns. Kerosene smell was detected.

The Trial Court acquitted all accused (Om Prakash - husband, Mangi Lal - father-in-law, Surji Devi - mother-in-law), disbelieving the prosecution witnesses on dowry demands and considering the possibility of accident or suicide.

The High Court, on appeal by the State, reversed the acquittal. It convicted Om Prakash under Section 304B IPC and sentenced him to 7 years RI. It also convicted Om Prakash, Mangi Lal, and Surji Devi under Section 498A IPC and sentenced them to 2 years RI each. Sentences were concurrent.
The accused (Respondents herein) did not appeal the High Court judgment; this appeal was filed by the State of Rajasthan seeking enhancement of sentence or conviction under Section 302 IPC.
The Supreme Court primarily examined the correctness of the High Court's conviction based on the evidence, despite the appeal's focus being enhancement (implicitly reviewing the conviction itself).
ipc_sections: Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty)
Section 302 (Punishment for murder) - Considered but not applied by HC/SC for conviction.
Section 113B, Indian Evidence Act, 1872 (Presumption as to dowry death)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court correctly reversed the perverse acquittal by the Trial Court, as evidence clearly established dowry demand and cruelty soon before death.
precedents: Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 (Principles for appeal against acquittal)
State of U.P. v. Banne @ Baijnath (2009) 4 SCC 271 (Reversal justified if trial court view is impossible or perverse)
Dhananjay Chatterjee v. State of W.B. (1994) 2 SCC 220 (Appellate court's power to review evidence)
elements: Appreciation of evidence by High Court

counter_arguments.loophole: Trial court's view regarding inconsistencies and possibility of suicide/accident was a plausible view, even if not the only one, limiting scope for reversal.
supporting_precedents: State of Rajasthan v. Raja Ram (2003) 8 SCC 180 (Acquittal not to be reversed merely because another view is possible)
C. Antony v. K.G. Raghavan Nair (2003) 1 SCC 1 (High standard for interfering with acquittal)

prosecution_arguments.argument: All ingredients of Section 304B IPC were satisfied against Om Prakash: Unnatural death (burns) within 7 years (4.5 months) of marriage, preceded by dowry-related cruelty and harassment.
precedents: Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 ('Soon before' implies proximate and live link, not necessarily immediate)
Satvir Singh v. State of Punjab (2001) 8 SCC 633 (Interpretation of S. 304B and S. 113B Evidence Act)
Shamnsaheb M. Multtani v. State of Karnataka (2001) 2 SCC 577 (Essential ingredients of S. 304B)
elements: Death otherwise than under normal circumstances

counter_arguments.loophole: Lack of specific, dated instances of cruelty immediately preceding the death weakens the 'soon before' requirement.
supporting_precedents: Balwant Singh v. State of Punjab (2004) 7 SCC 724 (Requirement of proximate link for 'soon before')
Sunil Bajaj v. State of M.P. (2001) 9 SCC 417 (Stray demands or incidents long before death may not satisfy 'soon before')

counter_arguments.loophole: The defence witness (DW-1) suggested accident/suicide, potentially rebutting the S.113B presumption.
supporting_precedents: Baijnath v. State of Madhya Pradesh (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Presumption is rebuttable; defence can show death unrelated to dowry demand)
Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116 (Circumstantial evidence must rule out innocence)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Evidence of persistent demands for TV/Fridge and consequent harassment proved cruelty under Section 498A against husband and in-laws.
precedents: Girdhar Shankar Tawade v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 5 SCC 177 (Definition and scope of cruelty under S. 498A)
State of Karnataka v. H.S. Srinivasa (2001) 4 SCC 505 (Testimony of close relatives regarding dowry demands is reliable)
Gananath Pattnaik v. State of Orissa (2002) 2 SCC 619 (Mental cruelty sufficient for S. 498A)
elements: Subjection to cruelty (harassment linked to unlawful demand)
Act committed by husband or relative

counter_arguments.loophole: Allegations against in-laws (Mangi Lal, Surji Devi) were somewhat general; specific roles might be hard to pinpoint.
supporting_precedents: Neelu Chopra v. Bharti (2009) 10 SCC 184 (Vague allegations against relatives insufficient for S. 498A)
Preeti Gupta v. State of Jharkhand (2010) 7 SCC 667 (Tendency to implicate all relatives requires careful scrutiny)

defense_arguments.argument: The Trial Court's acquittal was well-reasoned, based on contradictions in prosecution evidence and plausible defence of accident or suicide.
edge_cases: Appellate court's limited power to interfere with acquittal (CrPC S. 378)
Benefit of doubt must go to the accused when two views are possible
precedents: Arulvelu v. State (2009) 10 SCC 206 (Reversal of acquittal only if trial court findings are perverse or illegal)
Basappa v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 154 (High Court should be slow to disturb acquittal unless compelling reasons exist)
Ramesh Babulal Doshi v. State of Gujarat (1996) 9 SCC 225 (Acquittal reversal requires glaring errors in trial court findings)

defense_arguments.argument: Prosecution failed to establish a proximate and live link between alleged dowry demands/harassment and the death to satisfy the 'soon before death' requirement of Section 304B.
edge_cases: Interpretation of 'soon before' requires more than general allegations over months
Absence of any complaint by the deceased to authorities prior to death
precedents: Major Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 5 SCC 201 (Emphasis on proximate link for 'soon before')
Surinder Singh v. State of Haryana (2014) 4 SCC 129 (Temporal proximity is crucial)
Tarsem Singh v. State of Punjab (2008) 16 SCC 155 (Need for cogent evidence linking cruelty and death proximately)

defense_arguments.argument: The possibility of accidental death (stove burst) or suicide due to other reasons (e.g., difficulty adjusting to marital life, homesickness) was not ruled out by the prosecution.
edge_cases: Burden of proof rests entirely on the prosecution (beyond reasonable doubt)
Presence of kerosene can be consistent with cooking accident or suicide
precedents: State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh (1991) 3 SCC 1 (Prosecution must establish unnatural death linked to dowry cruelty)
Sanju alias Sanjay Singh Sengar v. State of M.P. (2002) 5 SCC 371 (Distinction between abetment of suicide (S. 306) and dowry death (S. 304B); requires proof beyond doubt)
Mangat Ram v. State of Haryana (2014) 12 SCC 595 (If suicide is a possibility, conviction under 304B requires strong evidence of preceding cruelty)

defense_arguments.argument: Allegations against the in-laws (Mangi Lal, Surji Devi) under Section 498A were general and omnibus, lacking specific evidence of their individual involvement in cruelty.
edge_cases: Over-implication of relatives is common in dowry cases
Lack of independent witness corroboration for specific acts by in-laws
precedents: Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 (Caution against implicating all family members routinely)
Geeta Mehrotra v. State of U.P. (2012) 10 SCC 741 (Need for specific allegations against each accused relative in S. 498A cases)
Bhaskar Lal Sharma v. Monica (2009) 10 SCC 604 (Court must ascertain specific roles of relatives)

judgment.outcome: Conviction upheld. The Supreme Court dismissed the State's appeal (which sought enhancement/conversion to S. 302) and thereby confirmed the High Court's judgment convicting Om Prakash under S. 304B IPC and Om Prakash, Mangi Lal, and Surji Devi under S. 498A IPC.
reasoning: The Supreme Court agreed with the High Court that the Trial Court's acquittal was perverse and ignored cogent evidence.
The testimonies of PW-2, PW-4, and PW-6 regarding dowry demands (TV, Fridge) and harassment were found credible and consistent.
The death was unnatural (burns) and occurred within 7 years (4.5 months) of marriage.

The term 'soon before death' under S. 304B does not mean 'immediately before'. It requires a proximate and live link. Given the short duration of marriage and continuous nature of demands/harassment testified to by witnesses, this link was established.
The presumption under Section 113B of the Indian Evidence Act was correctly raised against the husband (Om Prakash) for S. 304B, and he failed to rebut it.
The evidence was sufficient to establish cruelty under S. 498A against the husband and the in-laws based on persistent dowry demands and harassment.
The initial report by Om Prakash suggesting an accident was viewed as a potential attempt to create a false defense.
The High Court's appraisal of evidence was found to be sound.
